landingPage.title: How is it going with
landingPage.municipalitiesDescription: Annual emission reduction since the Paris Agreement in 2015
landingPage.bestCompanies: Companies that have reduced emissions the most
landingPage.aboutUsContent: Klimatkollen is a citizen platform that provides climate data and builds support for reduced emissions in line with the Paris Agreement. We believe in the power of simple and engaging data visualization to increase knowledge and engagement around the climate debate.

header.title: About Us
header.description: Klimatkollen is a citizen platform that provides climate data. Click on the headings to read more.

mainContent.title: What is Klimatkollen?
mainContent.paragraph1: Klimatkollen is a citizen platform that helps citizens, businesses, and organizations keep track of the climate transition by collecting and visualizing climate data.
mainContent.paragraph2: We show how emissions are progressing compared to how they should be, making it understandable for the public, contributing to a fact-based debate, and strengthening the opinion for climate actions.
mainContent.paragraph3: Our vision is for decision-makers in politics and business to be influenced by an informed and growing public to take actions that reduce emissions in line with the Paris Agreement.
mainContent.paragraph4: Klimatkollen was launched in March 2022 and is operated by the non-profit association Klimatbyrån. The initiators are Ola Spännar and Frida Berry Eklund. We started with local climate data for Swedish municipalities. From 2024, climate data will also be shown for companies.

financingSection.title: How We Are Funded
financingSection.paragraph1: In 2024 and 2025, Klimatkollen will receive financial backing from Google.org as one of two Swedish recipients of the Google.org Impact Challenge: Tech for Social Good.
financingSection.paragraph2: In 2023, Klimatkollen was supported by Postkodstiftelsen. The 2022 startup was financed by WWF Sweden, ClimateView, We Don't Have Time, and Argand Partners.
financingSection.paragraph3: Much of the work is voluntary, so we welcome more partners and financial support to scale up!
financingSection.donateDescription: Every krona gives us the strength to show more data.

previousProjectsSection.title: Previous Projects
previousProjectsSection.kommunprojektetDescription: In 2023, Klimatkollen received support from Postkodstiftelsen to assess the progress of the climate transition in municipalities. In addition to emission data, we also show what municipalities are doing to reduce them by presenting statistics on selected key figures for various sub-transitions.
previousProjectsSection.riksdagsvaletDescription: Before the 2022 parliamentary election, Klimatkollen was responsible for two unique projects:
previousProjectsSection.klimatmalText: An analysis of the political parties' climate goals for Sweden
previousProjectsSection.utslappsberakningText: Calculation of how emissions would decrease or increase with the parties' policies

header.title: Sources and Method
header.description: Our starting point is the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C target, and our data sources are public. Click on the headings to read more.

parisAgreement.title: Klimatkollen is based on the Paris Agreement
parisAgreement.paragraph1: The Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty between the world's countries aimed at limiting global warming to well below 2°C, with a target of 1.5°C.
parisAgreement.paragraph2: To meet this target, the world's countries must halve greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 levels and reach near-zero emissions by 2050. Currently, emissions are <0>still increasing</0> globally.
parisAgreement.paragraph3: According to the Paris Agreement, wealthy countries must take greater responsibility, as their significant historical emissions mean they have already used much of the remaining carbon space needed to curb global warming. Sweden is among these countries, which should lead the way in reducing emissions and also help other more vulnerable countries transition.

link.title: Paris Agreement
link.text: Read more about the Paris Agreement on the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency's website.

sources.title: About Our Sources
sources.paragraph1: Klimatkollen is based on public sources and verified data. We provide all sources so you can easily check and read more. If something is wrong, feel free to email us at hej@klimatkollen.se so we can make corrections.
sources.paragraph2: Company data is taken from the companies' own annual reports and sustainability reports.

co2Budgets.title: About Carbon Budgets
co2Budgets.paragraph1: A carbon budget indicates how much carbon dioxide can be released before the atmospheric CO2 level becomes high enough to exceed the 1.5°C target of the Paris Agreement.
co2Budgets.paragraph2: According to a <0>calculation</0> by researchers at Uppsala University and the Tyndall Centre in the UK, there are approximately 340 gigatons of CO2 left globally as of 2024, for a 50% chance of keeping the temperature increase under 1.5°C. At the current rate of emissions, the global budget will run out in about eight years.
co2Budgets.paragraph3: Based on the global budget, the researchers have also calculated how a national carbon budget for a fair climate transition would look for Sweden.
co2Budgets.paragraph4: The calculation shows that from January 2024, Sweden has a national carbon space of 80 million tons to align with the 1.5°C target. For an 83% chance of staying under a 2°C increase, the budget is 285 million tons. By comparison, Sweden's total greenhouse gas emissions in 2022 were 45.2 million tons.
co2Budgets.paragraph5: At Sweden's current emission rate, there are 1.8 years left of the 1.5°C budget and 6.4 years for 2°C. To align with 1.5°C, emissions in Sweden need to decrease by over 35% starting in 2024, or by 13.5% for 2°C.
co2Budgets.paragraph6: Klimatkollen has allocated the new national carbon budget (80 million tons, which also includes international aviation and shipping) to the country's municipalities using the same allocation method used to break down the global budget nationally.
co2Budgets.paragraph7: The local carbon budgets allow for comparisons of how emissions are progressing with how they should progress. Klimatkollen displays carbon budgets for municipalities both in numbers and as a development curve showing how emissions need to decrease to align with the Paris Agreement.
co2Budgets.paragraph8: In addition to the so-called Tyndall model that Klimatkollen uses, there are other ways to calculate a national carbon budget, for example, see Chalmers <0>here</0>.

emissionTypes.title: About Different Types of Emissions
emissionTypes.paragraph1: Klimatkollen is an independent fact platform that follows the general and established standards for how emissions are reported. The climate data we present reflects the delimitations based on how the carbon budget is calculated. For example, it is not possible to directly link carbon budgets to all greenhouse gas emissions, where methane, nitrous oxide, water vapor, and others are also included.
emissionTypes.paragraph2: Emissions from cement production are excluded in the IPCC's global carbon budget and therefore also in the carbon budget for Sweden and in the emission statistics for the three municipalities Gotland, Skövde, and Mörbylånga, where cement production currently occurs or has occurred in the past.
emissionTypes.paragraph3: Sweden also has a high climate impact from goods we import from other countries, causing emissions in other parts of the world. These consumption-based emissions are not included in the carbon budget.
emissionTypes.paragraph4: Nor are emissions from forests and land (so-called biogenic emissions) included in the carbon budget.
emissionTypes.paragraph5: In fact, the climate-impacting emissions are much larger than the territorial fossil carbon emissions usually reported by authorities and in the media, which are currently displayed on Klimatkollen.
emissionTypes.paragraph6: Klimatkollen is now investigating how other greenhouse gas emissions could be displayed on the website in the future, while keeping the possibility of comparing current emissions with carbon budgets.

scope.scope1: Emissions from owned or controlled sources by the organization.
scope.scope2: Indirect emissions from the production of purchased electricity, steam, heat, and cooling consumed by the organization.
scope.scope3: Indirect emissions from the organization’s value chain.
scope.biogenic: Biogenic emissions are carbon dioxide emissions from non-fossil (i.e., renewable) sources, such as the combustion of biofuels or by-products in paper production. According to the GHG protocol, these emissions are reported separately from scope 1-3, as they are an active part of the carbon cycle.

ola.description: Opinion leader, co-founder of Klimatkollen, former communications manager at the Centre Party, and client manager at Forsman & Bodenfors.

frida.description: Climate specialist and co-founder of Klimatkollen. Initiator of Our Kids' Climate and author of the book 'Talking to Children about Climate Change' (Natur & Kultur). EU Climate Pact Ambassador and Climate Reality Leader.

elvira.description: Tech lead and technical physicist at Klimatkollen and Precisit. Extensive experience in green and circular tech at several award-winning startups and part of the leadership team at IT consultancy firm Precisit.

christian.description: Award-winning developer, digital entrepreneur, and one of Sweden's most influential figures in tech. Founder of the digital innovation agency Iteam and co-founder of Open School Platform. Speaker on AI and digital innovation, advisor to the government.

hugo.description: Entrepreneurial climate enthusiast with a strong interest in how AI and technology can help solve future challenges.

kayla.description: Frontend developer with a passion for sustainability and user-friendly digital solutions. Previously worked as an environmental consultant focused on interpreting regulations and calculating greenhouse gas emissions for companies.

ola.description: Opinion leader, co-founder of Klimatkollen, former communications manager at the Centre Party, and client manager at Forsman & Bodenfors.

frida.description: Climate specialist and co-founder of Klimatkollen. Initiator of Our Kids' Climate and author of the book 'Talking to Children about Climate Change' (Natur & Kultur). EU Climate Pact Ambassador and Climate Reality Leader.

christian.description: Digital entrepreneur and one of Sweden's most influential figures in tech. CEO and founder of Iteam and Open School Platform.

anna.description: Digital strategist and former head of social media at Spotify and H&M. CEO and founder of Better Odds.

maria.description: Journalist, author, speaker, and founder of Klimatklubben. Named one of Sweden's 101 most influential sustainability figures in 2021.

carlJohan.description: Sustainability strategist at Diamant & Schulz, previously at Doings and Forsman & Bodenfors, author of the book 'Sustainability Transformation', awarded Marketing Book of the Year 2022.

realEstateScope3History.keyTrendsDescription: Scope 3 emissions in the real estate sector are often dominated by the categories 'Purchased Goods & Services' (1), 'Capital Goods' (2), and 'Energy-Related Activities' (3). These categories include construction materials, renovations, and energy use in buildings.
